Meta.ShortDescription: A long-term neuromuscular disease that leads to varying degrees of skeletal muscle weakness. The most commonly affected muscles are those of the eyes, face, and swallowing. It can result in double vision, drooping eyelids, trouble talking, and trouble walking. Onset can be sudden. Those affected often have a large thymus gland or develop a thymoma.[

Symptoms.Symptom: (Initial) Painless weakness of specific muscles, not fatique
Weakness of muscles can lead to swallowing difficulty
Inability to hold the mouth closed
Snarling appearance when attempting to smilie

Causes.Cause: Transmission defects in nerve impulses to muscles
Acetylcholine no longer produces muscle contractions

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Blood serum test for acetylcholine antibodies
Some patients without acetylcholine receptors have antibodies against the MuSK protein
Application of ice can raise the eyelid >2mm after the ice is removed.

Prognoses.Prognosis: The prognosis of MG patients is generally good, as is quality of life, given very good treatment.
In the early 1900s, the mortality associated with MG was 70%; now, that number is estimated to be around 3–5%, which is attributed to increased awareness and medications to manage symptoms.
